Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 1. Preface

This standard outlines the basis of the Shari’ah rulings on Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek, beginning with the rules relating to the promise to lease, if any, and concluding with the rules of repossession of the leased property in an operating Ijarah by the lessor or transferring its ownership in case of Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek, within or by the end of the lease term. The Standard also aims to outline the Shari’ah requirements that must be observed by Islamic financial Institutions (Institution/Institutions) with respect to Ijarah transactions.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 1. Scope of the Standard

This standard covers operating leases of properties or Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek, whether the Institution is the lessor or the lessee. This standard does not cover Sukuk al-Ijarah, as they are covered by Shari’ah Standard on Investment Sukuk, nor the employment of persons (labour contract), as it is covered by a separate standard.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 2. Promise to Lease (an Asset) > 2/1 Ijarah contract execution

An Ijarah contract is executed for an asset owned by the lessor or an usufruct owned by the sub-lessor. However, it is for a customer to request an Institution to acquire the asset or to acquire the usufruct of an existing asset which the customer wishes to take on lease.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 2. Promise to Lease (an Asset) > 2/2 Master agreement for Ijarah

Ijarah may be effected directly on the asset without any requirement of a preceding master agreement. It is permissible to have a master agreement covering a number of Ijarah transactions, setting out general terms and conditions. Separate lease contracts or notices may refer to the terms of the master agreement.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 2. Promise to Lease (an Asset) > 2/3 Payment for seriousness

The Institution may require the customer to pay a sum to ensure seriousness, with deductions made in cases proportional to actual damage if the promise is not fulfilled.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 2. Promise to Lease (an Asset) > 2/4 Security deposit handling

The money deposited by the customer as a security can be held on trust or on an investment trust basis, allowing the Institution to invest it. It's permissible to agree that this amount may be treated as an advance payment of lease instalments.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 3. Acquisition of the Asset to Be Leased, or Its Usufruct, by the Institution > 3/1 Requirements for an Ijarah contract

For an Ijarah contract concerning a specified asset, the lease contract should be preceded by acquisition of the asset or its usufruct.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 3. Acquisition of the Asset to Be Leased, or Its Usufruct, by the Institution > 3/1/1 Asset ownership by Institution

If the asset or its usufruct is owned by the Institution, an Ijarah contract may be executed upon agreement by the parties.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 3. Acquisition of the Asset to Be Leased, or Its Usufruct, by the Institution > 3/1/2 Asset acquisition by customer or third party

The Ijarah contract shall not be executed until the Institution has acquired the asset if it is to be acquired by the customer or a third party.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 3. Acquisition of the Asset to Be Leased, or Its Usufruct, by the Institution > 3/2 Leasing to the acquiring party

An asset may be acquired by a party and then leased to that party, without stipulating the Ijarah contract as a condition of the purchase contract.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 3. Acquisition of the Asset to Be Leased, or Its Usufruct, by the Institution > 3/3 Sub-lease conditions

A lessee may sub-lease an asset to a third party for variable rental amounts unless restricted by the lessor.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 3. Acquisition of the Asset to Be Leased, or Its Usufruct, by the Institution > 3/4 Leasing back to the lessor

A lessee may lease the asset back to its owner under certain conditions, avoiding contracts of 'Inah.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 3. Acquisition of the Asset to Be Leased, or Its Usufruct, by the Institution > 3/5 Ijarah for non-owned assets with specifications

An Ijarah contract may be executed for an asset promised for delivery with specific conditions, even if not owned by the lessor.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 3. Acquisition of the Asset to Be Leased, or Its Usufruct, by the Institution > 3/6 Joint acquisition and leasing

A customer may jointly acquire an asset with the Institution and lease the Institution's share, paying rental proportionate to the share owned.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 3. Acquisition of the Asset to Be Leased, or Its Usufruct, by the Institution > 3/7 Appointing a customer as agent

An Institution may appoint a customer as its agent to acquire an asset on its behalf, but it is preferable that the agent not be the prospective lessee.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 4. Concluding an Ijarah Contract and the Forms of Ijarah > 4/1 Signature of the contract and consequences

The lease contract is binding, with defined rules for terminations or alterations. The Ijarah period must be specified, potentially starting at a future date.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 4. Concluding an Ijarah Contract and the Forms of Ijarah > 4/1/1 Binding nature of the contract

The lease contract is binding, cannot be terminated or altered without mutual consent, with some termination provisions.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 4. Concluding an Ijarah Contract and the Forms of Ijarah > 4/1/2 Duration specification

The Ijarah period must be specified, commencing on the execution date unless a future date is agreed.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 4. Concluding an Ijarah Contract and the Forms of Ijarah > 4/1/3 Lessor's delivery obligations

No rental is due if the asset is not delivered by the specified date, with potential lease extensions.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 4. Concluding an Ijarah Contract and the Forms of Ijarah > 4/1/4 'Arboun (Earnest Money)

'Arboun is treated as an advance rental payment, with specific conditions regarding contract termination.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 4. Concluding an Ijarah Contract and the Forms of Ijarah > 4/2 Forms of the Ijarah contract > 4/2/1 Successive lease arrangements

Ijarah contracts can be executed in succession for the same asset with different lessees, not concurrently.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 4. Concluding an Ijarah Contract and the Forms of Ijarah > 4/2 Forms of the Ijarah contract > 4/2/2 Restriction during existing Ijarah

Lessor cannot sign another Ijarah for the same period or remaining period of an existing Ijarah.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 4. Concluding an Ijarah Contract and the Forms of Ijarah > 4/2 Forms of the Ijarah contract > 4/2/3 Ijarah with multiple lessees

Contracts can be signed with several lessees sharing the same usufruct, with usage time assigned.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 4. Concluding an Ijarah Contract and the Forms of Ijarah > 4/2 Forms of the Ijarah contract > 4/2/4 Sharing usufruct among lessees

A lessee may invite others to share usufruct before sub-leasing, allowing co-ownership in the usufruct.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5. Subject Matter of Ijarah > 5/1 Rules governing benefit and leased property > 5/1/1 Permissible use of leased assets

Leased asset must be usable preserving the asset, and benefit must be Shari’ah-compliant.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5. Subject Matter of Ijarah > 5/1 Rules governing benefit and leased property > 5/1/2 Usufruct of undivided assets

Subject matter can be a share in an undivided asset, benefiting by agreed means such as time-sharing.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5. Subject Matter of Ijarah > 5/1 Rules governing benefit and leased property > 5/1/3 Ijarah with non-Muslims

Ijarah may be executed with non-Muslims if the use is permissible.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5. Subject Matter of Ijarah > 5/1 Rules governing benefit and leased property > 5/1/4 Suitable use and care

Lessee must use the asset suitably, conforming to Shari’ah and avoiding damage.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5. Subject Matter of Ijarah > 5/1 Rules governing benefit and leased property > 5/1/5 Lessor's responsibility for defects

Lessor bears responsibility for defects impairing intended use, cannot exclude liability for impairment.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5. Subject Matter of Ijarah > 5/1 Rules governing benefit and leased property > 5/1/6 Lessee's obligation for misconduct

Lessee must repair or restore usufruct impaired by misconduct, without rent waiver during lost benefit.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5. Subject Matter of Ijarah > 5/1 Rules governing benefit and leased property > 5/1/7 Maintenance responsibilities

Lessor cannot stipulate major maintenance on lessee who can be tasked at lessor's cost, while ordinary maintenance by lessee.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5. Subject Matter of Ijarah > 5/1 Rules governing benefit and leased property > 5/1/8 Asset responsibility and insurance

Lessor maintains asset responsibility, may insure at own cost, factoring such into rental.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5. Subject Matter of Ijarah > 5/2 Rules governing lease rentals > 5/2/1 Form of lease rentals

Lease rental can be cash, goods, or services, specified either lump sum or not.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5 Responsibility and Maintenance > 5/1/5 Lessor’s responsibility for defects

The lessor must accept responsibility for any defects of the leased asset which impair the intended use of the asset, and may not exclude his liability for any impairment that the leased asset may sustain, either by his own doing or as a result of events outside his control, which affect the benefits intended to be available under the Ijarah contract.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5 Responsibility and Maintenance > 5/1/6 Lessee's responsibility for misconduct

If the benefit from the leased asset is impaired wholly or partially as a result of the lessee’s misconduct, while the property remains under lease, the lessee is obliged to restore or repair the usufruct, and rent for the time during which the benefit is lost is not to be waived.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5 Responsibility and Maintenance > 5/1/7 Maintenance responsibility

The lessor may not stipulate that the lessee will undertake the major maintenance of the asset that is required to keep it in the condition necessary to provide the contractual benefits under the lease. The lessor may delegate to the lessee the task of carrying out such maintenance at the lessor’s cost. The lessee should carry out operating or periodical (ordinary) maintenance.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5 Responsibility and Maintenance > 5/1/8 Lessor’s responsibility for the asset

The leased asset is the responsibility of the lessor throughout the duration of the Ijarah, unless the lessee commits misconduct or negligence. The lessor may take out permissible insurance on it whenever possible, and such insurance expenses must be borne by the lessor.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5/2 Rules governing lease rentals > 5/2/1 Rental specification

The lease rental may be in cash or in kind (goods) or benefit (service). The rental must be specified, either as a lump sum covering the duration of the Ijarah contract, or by instalments for parts of the duration.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5/2 Rules governing lease rentals > 5/2/2 Rental obligation commencement

The rental is made obligatory by the contract and the lessor’s entitlement to the rental runs from the time when the lessee starts to benefit from the asset or once the lessor makes the usufruct of the asset available to the lessee.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5/2 Rules governing lease rentals > 5/2/3 Floating rental conditions

In case the rental is subject to changes (floating rental), it is necessary that the amount of the rental of the first period of the Ijarah contract be specified in lump sum.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5/2 Rules governing lease rentals > 5/2/4 Rental split

It may be agreed that the rental should consist of two specified parts: one to be paid or transferred to the lessor and the other to be held by the lessee to cover any expenses or costs approved by the lessor.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 5/2 Rules governing lease rentals > 5/2/5 Amendment of future rentals

The amendment of future rentals is permissible by the agreement of both parties.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 6 Guarantees and Treatment of Ijarah Receivables > 6/1 Permissible security

Permissible security, of all kinds, may be taken to secure the rental payments or as a security against misuse or negligence on the part of the lessee.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 6 Guarantees and Treatment of Ijarah Receivables > 6/2 Advance rental payments

The two parties may agree that the rental be paid fully in advance. It is also permissible to make the rent payable in instalments.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 6 Guarantees and Treatment of Ijarah Receivables > 6/3 No increase in rental for delayed payment

No increase in the rental due may be stipulated by the lessor in case of delay in payment by the lessee.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 6 Guarantees and Treatment of Ijarah Receivables > 6/4 Donation for delayed payment

It may be provided in the contract that a lessee who delays payment for no good reason undertakes to donate a certain amount or percentage of the rental due in case of late payment.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 6 Guarantees and Treatment of Ijarah Receivables > 6/5 Foreclosure of security

In case of foreclosure of the security provided by the lessee, the lessor may deduct from such amounts only what is due in respect of rental for previous periods.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 7 Changes to the Ijarah Contract > 7/1 Selling of or damage to the leased asset > 7/1/1 Transfer of ownership to lessee

If the lessor sells the leased asset to the lessee, the Ijarah contract is terminated due to the transfer of the ownership of the leased asset and ownership of usufruct to the lessee.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 7 Changes to the Ijarah Contract > 7/1 Selling of or damage to the leased asset > 7/1/2 Sale to third parties

The lessor may sell the leased asset to a third party other than the lessee, and the title to the asset together with the rights and obligations of the lessor under the Ijarah contract is thereby transferred to the new owner.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 7 Changes to the Ijarah Contract > 7/1 Selling of or damage to the leased asset > 7/1/3 Total destruction of the leased asset

In case of total destruction of the leased asset, the Ijarah contract is terminated if it is concluded on an identified asset.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 7 Changes to the Ijarah Contract > 7/1 Selling of or damage to the leased asset > 7/1/4 Lessee’s liability for damage

The leased asset in the possession of the lessee is held by the lessee in a fiduciary capacity on behalf of the lessor.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 7 Changes to the Ijarah Contract > 7/1 Selling of or damage to the leased asset > 7/1/5 Partial destruction

In case of partial destruction of the leased asset in a manner that impairs the benefits expected from the leased asset, the lessee may terminate the Ijarah contract.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 7 Changes to the Ijarah Contract > 7/1 Selling of or damage to the leased asset > 7/1/6 Ijarah Mawsufah fi al-Dhimmah and asset replacement

In an Ijarah Mawsufah fi al-Dhimmah, the owner in cases of total and partial destruction must offer an alternative asset having a specification similar to that of the destroyed asset.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 7 Changes to the Ijarah Contract > 7/1 Selling of or damage to the leased asset > 7/1/7 Stopping use or return of asset

If the lessee stops using the leased asset or returns it to the owner without the owner’s consent, the rental will continue to be due.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 7 Changes to the Ijarah Contract > 7/2 Termination, expiry and renewal of the Ijarah contract > 7/2/1 Termination by mutual consent

It is permissible to terminate the lease contract by mutual consent but it is not permissible for one party to terminate it except in case of force majeure.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 7 Changes to the Ijarah Contract > 7/2 Termination, expiry and renewal of the Ijarah contract > 7/2/2 Termination for non-payment

The lessor may stipulate that the Ijarah contract be terminated if the lessee does not pay the rent or fails to pay it on time.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 7 Changes to the Ijarah Contract > 7/2 Termination, expiry and renewal of the Ijarah contract > 7/2/3 Ijarah contract continuation upon death

An Ijarah contract does not terminate with the death of either party thereto.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 7 Changes to the Ijarah Contract > 7/2 Termination, expiry and renewal of the Ijarah contract > 7/2/4 Expiry due to asset destruction

An Ijarah contract expires with the total destruction of the leased asset in the case of leasing a specific asset.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 7 Changes to the Ijarah Contract > 7/2 Termination, expiry and renewal of the Ijarah contract > 7/2/5 Pre-commencement termination

The two parties may terminate the Ijarah contract before it begins to run.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 7 Changes to the Ijarah Contract > 7/2 Termination, expiry and renewal of the Ijarah contract > 7/2/6 Lease expiry and renewal

The lease expires upon the expiry of its term, but it may remain operative for a good cause, such as the late arrival to the place intended in the lease of transportation vehicles.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8 Transfer of the Ownership in the Leased Property in Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8/1 Separate document for transfer

In Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek, the method of transferring the title in the leased asset to the lessee must be evidenced in a document separate from the Ijarah contract document.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8 Transfer of the Ownership in the Leased Property in Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8/2 Binding promise by lessor

A promise to transfer the ownership by way of one of the methods specified is a binding promise by the lessor.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8 Transfer of the Ownership in the Leased Property in Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8/3 New contract for ownership transfer

In all cases of transfer of ownership by way of gift or sale, it is necessary, when the promise is fulfilled, that a new contract be drawn up.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8 Transfer of the Ownership in the Leased Property in Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8/4 Contingent gift and payment

In case the Ijarah contract is combined, through a separate document, with a gift contingent upon the condition that the remaining rent instalments be paid, the ownership is transferred to the lessee if the condition is fulfilled.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8 Transfer of the Ownership in the Leased Property in Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8/5 Avoidance of 'Inah

If the leased asset was purchased from the lessee before it was leased back to the lessee, a period of time must have expired to avoid the contract of 'Inah.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8 Transfer of the Ownership in the Leased Property in Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8/6 Application of Ijarah rules

Subject to item 8/8, the rules governing Ijarah must apply to the Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8 Transfer of the Ownership in the Leased Property in Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8/7 Future sale contract execution

Transfer of the ownership cannot be made by executing, along with the Ijarah, a sale contract that will become effective on a future date.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8 Transfer of the Ownership in the Leased Property in Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > 8/8 Adjustment of rental in case of destruction

If the leased asset is destroyed or if the continuity of the lease contract becomes impossible, then the rental is adjusted based on the prevailing market value.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Adoption of the Standard

The Shari'ah standard for Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek was adopted by the Shari'ah Board in its meeting No. (4) held on 25–27 Safar 1421 A.H., corresponding to 29–31 May 2000 A.D. In its meeting No. (8) held in Mecca on 28 Safar - 4 Rabi’ I, 1423 A.H., corresponding to 11–16 May 2002 A.D., the Shari'ah Board readopted a resolution to reformat the Shari'ah rules for Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek in the form of a Shari'ah standard.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix (A) Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 1/1 First Meeting Decision

In its meeting No. (1) held on 11 Dhul-Hajjah 1419 A.H., corresponding to 27 February 1999 A.D., the Shari'ah Board decided to give priority to the preparation of the Shari'ah rules for Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix (A) Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 1/2 Fatwa and Arbitration Committee Commission

On Tuesday 13 Dhul-Hajjah 1419 A.H., corresponding to 30 March 1999 A.D., the Fatwa and Arbitration Committee decided to commission a Shari'ah consultant to prepare a juristic study and an exposure draft on the Shari'ah Rules for Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix (A) Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 1/3 Exposure Draft Amendments

In its meeting held on 13–14 Rajab 1420 A.H., corresponding to 22–23 October 1999 A.D., the Fatwa and Arbitration Committee discussed the exposure draft of the Shari'ah Rules for Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek, and asked the consultant to make the amendments in light of the comments made by the members.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix (A) Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 1/4 Shari’ah Board Amendments

The revised exposure draft of the Shari’ah Rules was presented to the Shari’ah Board in its meeting No. (3) held in Mecca on 10–15 Ramadan 1420 A.H., corresponding to 18–22 December 1999 A.D. The Shari’ah Board made further amendments to the exposure draft of the Shari’ah Rules and decided that it should be distributed to specialists and interested parties in order to obtain their comments in order to discuss them in a public hearing.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix (A) Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 1/5 Public Hearing

A public hearing was held in Bahrain on 29–30 Dhul-Hajjah 1421 A.H., corresponding to 4–5 April 2000 A.D. The public hearing was attended by more than 30 participants representing central institutions, accounting firms, Shari’ah scholars, academics and others who are interested in this field.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix (A) Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 1/6 Joint Committee Meeting

The Shari’ah Standards Committee and the Fatwa and Arbitration Com- mittee held a joint meeting on 21–23 Muharram 1421 A.H., corresponding to 26–28 April 2000 A.D., to discuss the comments made about the Shari’ah Rules.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix (A) Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 1/7 Board Approval

The Shari’ah Board in its meeting No. (4) held on 25–27 Safar 1421 A.H. corresponding to 29–31 May 2000 A.D., in Al-Madinah Al-Munawwarah discussed the amendments made by the Shari’ah Studies Committee and the Fatwa and Arbitration Committee, and made the amendments which it considered necessary.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix (A) Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 1/8 Standard Formatting

In its meeting No. (8) held in Al-Madinah Al-Munawwarah on 28 Safar - 4 Rabi’ I, 1423 A.H. corresponding to 11–16 May 2002 A.D., the Shari’ah Board adopted the reformatting of Shari’ah Rules for Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek in the name of Shari’ah Standard No. (9).

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix (A) Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 1/9 Review Committee Meeting

The Shari’ah Standards Review Committee reviewed the standard in its meeting held in Rabi’ II, 1433 A.H. corresponding to March 2012 A.D., in the State of Qatar, and proposed after deliberation a set of amendments.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix (A) Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard > 1/10 Final Approval Meeting

In its meeting No. (39) held in the Kingdom of Bahrain on 13–15 Muharram 1435 A.H., corresponding to 6–8 November 2014 A.D., the Shari’ah Board discussed the proposed amendments submitted by the Shari’ah Standards Review Committee and approved necessary amendments.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix B: The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > 1/1 Permissibility of Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek

Ijarah derives permissibility from the Qur’an, the Sunnah, consensus of Fuqaha and Ijtihad (reasoning). Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek is a form of Ijarah with a promise by the lessor to transfer ownership at the end of the Ijarah term.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix B: The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > 1/2 Differences from Hire-Purchase

In hire-purchase, the terms of sale and leasing are applied simultaneously, transferring ownership once the last installment is paid. In permissible Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek, ownership is transferred at the end of the Ijarah term.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix B: The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > 1/3 Promise to Lease an Asset

The basis for allowing payment requests by a promissor is to confirm the commitment. A Fatwa on Hamish Jiddiyyah (security deposit) in Murabahah is applicable to Ijarah.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix B: The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > 1/4 Acquisition of the Asset to be Leased

Leasing of an asset not owned by the lessor is prohibited. The basis for allowing leasing back an asset to a previous owner is it doesn’t involve an ’Inah sale.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix B: The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > 1/5 Contract of Ijarah

The basis for the binding nature of an Ijarah contract is that it involves an exchange of counter-values, supported by the saying of Allah: 'Fulfil (your) obligations...'.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix B: The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > 1/6 Subject Matter of Ijarah

The leased asset must be usable while preserving its essence. Use in impermissible ways makes the lessor an accomplice in wrongdoing.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix B: The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > 1/7 Guarantees and Treatment of Ijarah Receivables

Guarantees are permissible to secure performance. Accelerated payment clauses are based on the Prophet's saying: 'Muslims are bound by the conditions they made'.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix B: The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > 1/8 Changes to the Ijarah Contract

The lessor can sell the leased asset without the lessee's consent, provided it doesn't affect the lessee's usufruct rights.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix B: The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard > 1/9 Transfer of the Ownership in the Leased Asset in Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek

Documents of the lessor’s promise to sell must be separate from the Ijarah contract to ensure no linking of liabilities.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix C: Definitions > 2/1 Ijarah

Ijarah means leasing of property under a contract for a specified benefit for a specified period in return for a specified consideration.

Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek > Appendix C: Definitions > 2/2 Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek

A form of leasing with a promise by the lessor to transfer ownership to the lessee, either at the end of the period or by stages.
